text:
ANNOUNCER: The
following content is provided by MIT OpenCourseWare
under a Creative Commons License.

Additional information
about our license and MIT OpenCourseWare
in general is available at ocw.mit.edu.

JEREMY WOLFE: OK. We could continue. Last time I was
talking about cognition

and framing the argument in
part in saying that we're not

like computers even
though computers are nice metaphors for various
aspects of cognitive function.

We could continue that today. When you get an
off-the-shelf computer, you expect that its basic way
of thinking is going to be--

it's there. You might have to
put programs on it to teach it to do
specific things,

but you don't have to
educate its motherboard or something of that sort. With kids, it's not
clear that that's

the case, that if you take
an off-the-shelf baby, it's not clear that
that baby is thinking

the way that an
adult is thinking, and that's really what I
want to talk about today.

Let me put up a
picture that I can then return to multiple times.

If this is age and we're
interested in development, what

we were talking about last time
is the adult state, something

about the adult state. What we want to know in
studying cognitive development--

or any development is,
what's the starting point?

If you have a newborn baby,
is that baby starting at 0 or does that baby come with
an innate endowment that

allows them-- that gets them on the way
towards the adult state?

And then what does the
transition from the kid state

to the adult state look like? Does it look like some
gradual improvement?

Does it look like
some step function? It might be useful to describe
from the realm of vision

a couple of examples just
to show you what this means. If you want to know what a
baby sees, if you go and--

we'll go over here. If you give yourself--
get yourself a newborn off-the-shelf baby
and give them--

well, you can't give
them an eye chart to read because they can't read. So you give them the
illiterate E chart,

as it's called in
the trade, and-- whoops, well, now and so on.

And you ask them which
way the letters point, the kid doesn't tell
you anything useful

because the kid can't
answer that question. However, conveniently enough, if
you take-- even a newborn baby,

as young as you can test
them, and put them in front of a couple of screens,
a little peephole here--

you guys can all be babies,
and I, the experimenter, would be looking out at
you through this peephole,

if you put black and white
bars on one screen and you put

on the other screen a gray of
the same average luminance-- So if this is 0 and that's 100,
this is 50 all over the place,

if the baby can see the bars,
conveniently enough, that baby will look at the bars.

And if you are
looking at the baby, you can figure out-- move
the bars from side to side,

from trial to trial,
you can figure out where that baby
is looking and you can figure out where
the bars are based

on where the baby is looking. That's known as a preferential
looking method, very useful in infant research.

And what you discover, if
you do experiments like this, studying infant
visual acuity, is

that babies don't start at 0. Babies don't start--
newborn baby isn't blind.

Newborn baby can see something. If normal adult vision
is around 20/20,

newborn baby vision
is around 24/100. It's the big E at the top
of the eye chart, roughly.

And the progression from the
infant state to the adult state

is a gradual, relatively
steady increase over about the first
couple of years of life.

Every month, you get roughly
the same kind of improvement until you hit the adult level.

So not a zero starting point
and a gradual improvement

to adult levels. Now let's take a different
example from the same realm. Remember, you've got two eyes.

The difference is in those two
eyes are a depth cue, known as binocular stereopsis.

Well, the cue is
binocular disparity, the ability is stereoscopic
depth perception.

If you test a baby-- so babies, it turns
out, also like things that stand
out in depth better

than they like flat stuff. So if you show a baby bars
standing out in depth, a newborn baby gives you squat.

To all appearances, there
is no binocular stereovision in a newborn baby.

And for about the first three
to five months, nothing happens.

And then, over a very
short period of time-- I should get rid of
this other step function

just to not confuse matters. Over a very short
period of time,

performance rises to
essentially the adult level as if this was waiting for
something to get wired up

in the brain-- when it got
wired up in the brain, bingo, the kid is fine. Oh, by the way, if you
are a woman person,

you got there first. It turns out to be a
reliable sex difference that females get binocular
stereovision a month

or so before males. Does this make any
difference to anything? No, but we've found
it years and years ago

when I was a grad student,
so I still remember it. So these are two of the
various possibilities
for a function like this-- for a developmental course. And we're going to look at--

we're going to talk about
three specific realms

of cognitive development
in which there

are classic demonstrations
of children doing things differently than
adults do them, and I

will try to take
each of those apart and to give you
some idea of what's

the starting point,
what's the ending point, and how do we get between those. The three, which are
outlined on the handout,

have to do with number,
so-called childhood animism,

and egocentric behavior. Let me describe each of
these problems to you in turn

and then we'll take
each of them apart. The classic-- these
are all demonstrations

that originally come
from the work of Jean Piaget, the great
early-mid 20th-century

developmental psychologist,
who, among other things bequeathed to us a great
collection of phenomena that

show striking differences
between the way kids behave and the way adults behave and
that cry out for explanation.
So here would be one of them. These are M&Ms, let us say.
[VOCALIZING]  That will do.

Oh, I'm running out of space
here for my M&Ms. Well, people over there
can't see them.

Can you see that M&M? Wait a second, I'll
put them down here.

That'll work.  There we go. Don't worry about
these M&Ms. OK.

This is another one of those
forced choice kind of things. So think hard about this. Are there more
M&Ms here or here?
How many vote up? That's good.

However, if you were three,
four, five, maybe even six,

you'd stay here. You would be perfectly happy. You think, that's
good, that's nice.

It makes math a little
more difficult here at MIT, but you should-- but we shouldn't
stifle your creativity.

That's good. And so the first
obvious thought is,

well, the kid's just not quite
understanding the question. It's a language-y kind of thing.

We're saying, "where is more?" And they're saying
"Which is longer?" So that's why it's important
that you use M&Ms. You say, OK,
kid, which pile would you like? Kid says, I want this pile.
Why do you want this pile? Well, there's more there. Ah.

And, in fact, this
is why you shouldn't be born to a psychologist,
because your psychologist

dad is always tricking
you out of the candy by playing this game on you. It works.

You teach this
stuff long enough-- because this is really true. And then you've got yourself
like a three-year-old kid

and you mess with his
brain and yeah, it's true. [LAUGHTER] This is good stuff.

So you want to know what's-- the question here, of course,
is then, what's going on?

This is part of a
general problem. If you take-- so let's
take a fat beaker.

Here's a big fat beaker
with this much fluid in it. Now I pour that into
a narrow beaker.

The water-- the fluid level is-- STUDENTS: Higher. JEREMY WOLFE: Higher. Is there more fluid now than
there was when it was here?

No. Does a little kid
think there is? Yes.

If you let the little kid pour
it back into the big bowl now, he thinks there's less now.

Take a ball of clay,
roll it out into a snake, there's more clay,
says the little kid.

Squish it back together,
now there's less. These are so-called
conservation problems. We're particularly
interested in the version

that has to do with number. How come they think, in this
case, that 5 is bigger than 6?

Second problem is what's
called childhood animism.

The classic Piagetian version
would involve something like--

well, something exactly like
his so-called three-mountain apparatus where he
had a tabletop--

he's from Switzerland,
so he's into the Alps. So it's a tabletop
version of the Alps.

And on the Alps, are things
like-- that's a river, and that's a hut.

[LAUGHTER] It's-- yeah, it's where
the pie-maker lives, right?

[LAUGHTER] So anyway. But the point is that
you're sitting here looking at this thing. You're like a three-year-old
or something looking at this.

And mom's over there
on the other side. You can see mom.

And the question
that you're asked is, can your mother
see the river?

And you say, yeah, sure. As if the fact that you
could see the river makes

you think that she
can see the river. As if you couldn't
take her point of view. At least Piaget thought
that the problem here

is that you can't quite take
somebody else's point of view. My favorite anecdotal version of
this is a story of a little kid

out to eat with his brother
at some burger place.

Little kid wants more French
fries, and so he does this.

On the theory, presumably, if
I can't see what I'm doing, you can't see what I'm doing.

So there-- most people
don't do that by the time they reach adulthood.

So there's something
to explain there. That's childhood-- that's
not childhood animism at all,
actually. That's egocentric behavior. Sorry. I misspoke.

That's the third example
that we'll get to. So egocentric, that
makes more sense. Egocentric is the inability to
see things from somebody else's

vantage point. So I've just described
to you the problem of childhood egocentrism. Childhood animism is
a tendency to declare

things to be alive that you
would not declare to be alive. Is the cat alive? Yeah, fine.

Is the sun alive? Yes. Is the cloud-- are
the clouds alive? Yes. Little kids will assert that
and you typically will not.

That's animism. Piaget understood that as a
problem with mapping concepts

onto a discrete set of
entities out in the world, and so we'll take a
look at that, too.

So, number, animism,
egocentric behavior, those are the things that I
want to talk about today.

Let's start with number. And let's start by taking
apart the idea of number a bit

because you and I tend
to think of number as--

there's five of those things,
and six of those things. Number-- the concept of
number, the idea of number

can be broken down into three
different bits, at least.

And let's see if I
can do this right. Whoop. Oh. Well, they went by. How many warthogs were there?
Six? Who knows? Some number. Wait a second. Let's try this again.
STUDENT: Eight. JEREMY WOLFE: All right. Nine, eight. Seven.

Some number like that. It wasn't 115, but
how about this? STUDENTS: Two. JEREMY WOLFE: Yeah, OK.
That's good. Whoops. How about this? STUDENTS: Three. JEREMY WOLFE: Whoops. How about that? That was a--
[LAUGHTER] How about this? This is data.

If you do this
task, what you find is that people are essentially
perfect for 1, 2, and 3, maybe

4. And then it falls off. They start-- I think
the answer was 8 before, but sometimes you'll say
7, sometimes you say 9.

And so your percent correct,
being absolutely correct will systematically fall off.

And if I put 1,500
warthogs up there, you'll just not get
it right at all. Similarly, if I was to
measure not percent correct,

but reaction time, the
reaction time for 1, 2, 3, 4 would be essentially
flat, and then

start to roughly
linearly increase. That linear increase could be--

for a number like
8, could either be due to some
counting operation. Or how many people--

somebody tell-- somebody who
thinks they saw eight of them, tell me how they
figured that out. Yeah?

STUDENT: You saw a line
of 5 and a 2 and 1. JEREMY WOLFE: A line
of 5 and 2 and 1. OK.

That's-- yeah, yeah. STUDENT: Well, it kind of
came after they went away. JEREMY WOLFE: Oh, OK, yes. If I was doing this as
a proper experiment,

I would have masked
it so you couldn't count like the afterimage
or the iconic memory. So there-- yep.

STUDENT: Just
recall the picture? JEREMY WOLFE: OK. So you were also dumping
it out of iconic memory

in some fashion. But the answer I was
fishing for is something like the 5, 2, and 1 thing. You can count those
displays, and in fact,

the people who got them back
later might have done this, too, by more typically saying,
oh, there's one group of four,

there's another group of four. This ability to handle small
numbers is called subitizing.

And it works for small
numbers like 1, 2, 3, 4. You have some
immediate appreciation

of that number-- of
those small numbers. That's different than your
appreciation of 8 or 17 or 150.

OK, that's one
warthog demonstration.

How about, which one
has more warthogs?

How many vote that
there were more here? How many vote that
there were more here? Yeah, OK, you got that.

You knew-- how many
warthogs were there here?
A lot, yeah. And how many warthogs were here? A lot, but not as many.

Well, you can go back. There we go. You could count
these, obviously, but you didn't count them. And you didn't subitize them.

What you did was got
some general impression of their numerosity because--

well, this is-- if you go back
to the perception chapter,

this is another Weber's
law kind of thing, or the money example
from last time.

You can also decide something
about how many things there
by a ratio comparison. There's more here than here.

If there were 750 here and 745
here, you wouldn't know that.

There has to be a critical
proportional difference between the two. But given a
proportional difference,

this is something
like 2 to 1, it doesn't matter how
many things there are. You simply know that there's
more here and less here.

That's a crude
sense of numerosity. The variety of--
what we typically

think of when we think about
numbers is counting things. And that's the third property. So here, you can count them.

Somebody can go and figure out
exactly how many warthogs there are there. You just have to go through
and use your counting ability
to figure that out. You have that ability.

It seems to be critically
piggybacked on your ability-- on linguistic ability.

Recent interesting evidence
for that comes from-- I don't know how to
pronounce it properly, but something like
the Piraha tribe

in the Amazon, their number
terms consist of 1, 2, and more

than that. And the result is that they bomb
tasks that require counting.

They can do subitizing tasks,
they can do numerosity tasks,

but they don't do
counting tasks. And they will fail-- they fail versions of
the M&M task, in effect.

You say, which of
these boxes has-- do you want-- they've
got fish in them

or something like that
and one has a little label with, I think, four
fish on the top and another has five
fish on the top. And as far as these
guys are concerned,

it's all just got lots of fish. What you see here is a
task where they were--

this was the
experimenter's marks, and the Piraha person was
asked to just copy it so one.

I make one mark, two, I can
make that two marks, three. That's just a bunch, I'll
make a bunch of marks.

Once you got out of
the subitizing range, they simply didn't do
simply do the task.

I think I put
these guys on the-- this article from which
I stole this picture

may live on the website. I seem to remember that
that was one of the things that I posted there.

So, what do kids have
and how does that tie into the M&M problem?

Well, turns out that
little kids have--

babies have this
numerosity, Weber's law,

comparison kind of
numerosity ability. And here's an experiment
done by Shu and Liz Spelke

up at Harvard that illustrates
that you're a baby, you're looking at this,
and every now and then,

the display changes. Boink. Yeah, OK, there's
another bunch of dots.

And another bunch of dots. And what I'm doing is I, the
experimenter, and measuring how long you look at this.

And I'm changing the shape and
the distribution of these guys, but I'm not changing the number.

And you are slowly
getting bored. Or to be more technical
about it, you're habituating.

You may recall that from
the learning chapter.

I don't think we talked about
it in the chapter-- well, we can talk about it right now.

Oh, a bunch of people
oriented to that.

And now those people
are having no problem at all seeing back out again. That's habituation.

You do it, babies do it, slugs
do it, everybody does it. It's great. Useful technique, because the
baby's sitting here saying,

this is all more
or less the same and it's just not
that interesting.

Whoa, wait a second, that's
interesting, says the baby.

And the baby says
it by looking more. What happens here is that
looking time goes down,

down, down, down, is the number
on each trial stays the same. Then when you jump from
8 to 16, the baby says,

hey, something's happened, I've
got to take a look at this. Do 16 for a while and blah,
blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah.

And what this tells
you is that the baby could tell the difference
between 8 and 16.

The reason for changing the
shape and the distribution and the density
and stuff like that is to make sure that that's
not what you're picking up on.

And Shu and Spelke were
careful about that. So what you're picking
up on here is numerosity.

Babies can do that, but
if you go from 8 to 9,

nothing happens here. In fact, if you go from 8 to
12, a 50% increase in dots,
nothing happens here with-- how old are these babies? Six-month-old babies.

So 8 to 16, a 2-to-1 change,
that babies pick up on. So, one thing we know--
let me get my graph back here-- Oops. Graph, come back, graph.

Get my graph back down here. So we know that if we're
talking about number,

the starting spot isn't 0
for number-sense in infants.

The numerosity piece, some
chunk of the numerosity piece

is there for starters. Perhaps more dramatically,
the subitizing piece is there,

and the subitizing
piece is there along with what seems to be an
innate mathematical ability.

Little kids can
add and subtract. Babies can add and subtract.

This was a surprise. And I can-- this is
work done by Karen Wynn

and it is worth making
the historical note that she was a TA for this
course once upon a time,

now a professor at Yale. But in any case, she
figured out that babies can add and subtract.

Look, if you ask a
baby, what's 1 plus 1? You get much the same answers. If you ask the baby, which
way is the E pointing?

You gotta get clever
about this sort of thing. And here's how Karen
got clever about it.

So, you're looking at a screen. You're a little baby looking
at a screen like this,

and you see a hand come
in with an object-- [VOCALIZING] sticking-- it
probably wasn't a warthog,

but I had this
warthog lying around as an image on my
computer for some reason. OK.

So-- eh, and you see a hand
come in with another one. OK.

You got a pretty good
idea what's going on here. So if I lift the screen--

[VOCALIZING] what do
you expect to see? [LAUGHTER]

All right. Now let's-- we
can do this again. Whoop. Whoop. OK. The speed would be
the same, of course,

I just didn't want to keep
sliding them in slowly. I'll move to screen again.

They you are. [LAUGHTER] And the baby will respond
to this by looking longer.

The baby will say-- the baby will say. Who knows what
the baby will say? But the baby is apparently,
in effect, saying,

I put one thing in there,
so two things are in there. I guess two-- there
must be two stuffs. Two warthogs back there.

Lift it up, and now
there's only one warthog, and this violates the
rules of the universe

and I better look
at this for a while to figure out what's going on. And you can use this technique
to show that babies can do--
I have a subtraction one here? I forget. No, that's going to-- I did that already.
Yeah, yeah, yeah. Did habituate. Oh, nope. It works for monkeys, too.

We'll talk about
that in a minute. But you can do this--
you can do addition, you can do subtraction. So subtraction.

You put-- you have
the two things here, you put down the
screen, the hand comes in and pulls one out.

When the screen comes up,
the baby expects to see one. If the baby sees zero
or the baby sees two,

the baby says, something
weird is going on here and I need to I need to
think about this for a while.

Now, if you do this
with big numbers outside of the subitizing
range, you don't get the result.

So you stick 15
warthogs back there and you lift up the screen
and there's 13 warthogs

and the kid says, I don't care. Once you get above
about three with babies,

it doesn't work anymore. So what you get is evidence
for subitizing being present

and some addition
and subtraction kind of operation
for essentially

as early as you want to test it. You can also get these
abilities in animals-- that's what this
slide is intended

to remind me to tell you. Animals, certainly
macaque monkeys

will show numerosity
effects and they can also do this Karen Wynn-style math.

They prefer eggplants. At least Mark Hauser's
monkeys like eggplant,

so that's why they
are eggplants here. And you worry about
doing this in the lab because maybe your
lab monkeys have

led this elaborately studied
life and are kind of smart. So Hauser went down to this
island in the Caribbean

where he's got a free-ranging
troop of monkeys, and then you have to coax
them into playing your game.

So you're hanging--
there's this great video that Mark has of monkeys. He's hanging out
with his eggplants,

and then he's starting to
do this eggplant puppet show with the macaque is looking
longer at the weird ones.

And the guy put
two eggplants there and there's only one
there now, now what? Hope he's going to feed me some
of these eggplants eventually.

But in any case,
monkeys can do the task. Monkeys will look
longer at things that violate their expectation.

However, monkeys
don't count, at least they don't count the way
that you and I count.

And this goes for great apes. Let's go find the brightest
beast other than humans

that we can. There's at least one chimp who's
been trained for 20 years--

oh, I misspoke when I talked
about this in concourse. I said he'd been
trained for nine years and never gotten past 20.

It's worse than that. He's been trained for
20 years and he's never gotten past nine.

He can count to nine-- do pretty good stuff
up to nine, but he's doing this by basically
association learning.

Up you go. And let's turn that on
and let it come back up.

You can train the
monkey to realize that this sign or this graphic
or something means nine things,

but this is very different
from what you and I can do. It didn't take you 20 years
and you got well beyond nine.

Counting seems to be heavily
dependent on two things.

One is language and the other is
an act of inductive reasoning.

And you can see
counting happening, the development of counting
in a series of steps.

Kids, as they are
learning language, learn that there is
this game about saying,

1, 2, 3, 4, and so on that
parents really like to play.

If you start counting, they'll
give you the cookies and stuff.

Good things happen. They don't have
any particular clue that this-- initially that
this maps on to anything

in particular. And so what you get with
two-and-a-half-year-old kids is

a two-and-a-half-year-old kid,
if you ask for one cookie,

will give you one cookie. But if you ask for
anything else-- give me two cookies,
give me four cookies,

give me whatever, they'll
give you some random-- here, have some cookies. It's one and other stuff.

Eventually, they learn
to map the counting

onto the subitizing range and
then start blowing it later.

So if you have little
sibs or cousins or stuff that you've
hung around with,

you may have seen
them counting things. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 12.

And they've got this notion
that the numbers keep going in some fashion,
but once you get out of the small numbers,
it's not terribly clear

what's going on there. But even in this
stage, you can start to see the development of
something more sophisticated.

Six. They may not know
how many sixes. They know 6 is a lot of stuff.

If you ask for six
cookies, you'll get some arbitrary
number of cookies.
But if you ask a little kid--

if I take a lot of
cookies and I add a few,

do I still have
a lot of cookies? Kid says, yeah. Yeah that works.

Kid says-- and so all right. So we know that. OK, now, if I have six cookies,
can you give me six cookies?

Some random number of cookies. OK. If I have six
cookies and I give-- and I add some more cookies,
do I still have six cookies?

No. You've got a lot of cookies, but
it's not the same "a lot of." So even when they don't really
know how many cookies you've

got, they have the notion
that the number names

are naming something specific. They don't quite get
what it is, but it's something specific in a way
that a term like "a lot" is not.

Eventually, you make
the breakthrough
that you can count, basically. And that you can keep--

and if you add one
to each of them, you can just keep
doing this forever. This is-- again, I don't
know how much you hang around

with little kids or
remember your own experience because this is getting old
enough that you might actually

remember this state yourself,
of asking what the biggest

number in the world is? Anybody remember asking what the
biggest number in the world is? Yeah, all right.

Most of you got-- that's the
problem with MIT students, they figured all this stuff out
when they were like two instead of--

[LAUGHTER] So anyway. You have little kids want
to know what the biggest number in the world is.

And so you say to the
little kid, well, what do you think the biggest
number in the world is? Well, it's a million.

OK. What happens if we
had a million plus 1? Is there a number for that?

[MUMMBLING] There's a
million and one, I guess. Well, I guess a million
and one is the biggest number in the world.

Always, we're adding it. A million and two. And you can keep doing
this for a while. Eventually, around the time when
you get in this conversation,

the kid catches on to the
notion that you can always

get a bigger one. And this is really-- this
leads to very boring car rides,

sometimes. Do you want to see
how high I can count? That's a kind of cute game
with a three-year-old.

Oh, look, he can get
all the way to 20. By the time you get a four or
five-year-old, million and one,

million and two,
million and three. OK, we've made it to
California, kid, shut up!

So, what you get is,
you've got this base--

you've got this basic numeric
competence or core knowledge, as Liz Spelke would
call it, and then you're

waiting for the
development of language. When you get language, you can
then get this counting piece

to work. When you got the
counting piece to work, you can combine it
with your ability to make the inductive leap
that numbers go on forever.

And then you're in a
position to go off to school and learn some math. So the ability-- I mean,
there's, in a sense,

not an adult level of
numerical competence. You guys it's know more
about numbers than I know,

I would imagine. But the ability to go off
